headline: Access international arbitration and mediation services
description: Seek dispute resolution through the WIPO Arbitration and Mediation Center

usageInfo.name: Disclaimer and Feedback Policy
usageInfo.text: This IP First Response website has been designed to help IP rights holders navigate IP infringement and enforcement by making it visible, accessible, and to provide information about the factors involved in pursuing different options. It does not provide legal, business or other professional advice, and none of the content should be regarded as recommending a specific course of action. We welcome any feedback via our IP First Response feedback form and by emailing us.

isPartOf.name: IP First Response
isPartOf.description: A first port of call for businesses to easily understand complex intellectual property issues.

mainEntity.name: Access international arbitration and mediation services
mainEntity.description: Seek dispute resolution through the WIPO Arbitration and Mediation Center

mainEntity.name: How to proceed with Access international arbitration and mediation services

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: To receive information and procedural assistance from the WIPO Center, you can contact [*arbiter.mail@wipo.int*](mailto:arbiter.mail@wipo.int) or file a Request for [Good Offices](https://www.wipo.int/amc/en/goodoffices/) using the [WIPO Good Office](https://www.wipo.int/amc-forms/adr/good-offices-services) Services

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: If you are facing a dispute related to intellectual property, innovation, or technology, you can book a free online Orientation Session with the [WIPO Arbitration and Mediation Center](https://www.wipo.int/amc/en/index.html) for assistance at: [How can WIPO assist in resolving intellectual property disputes?](https://www.wipo.int/amc/en/center/adr-assistance.html)

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: If parties are already facing a dispute, and in the absence of a mediation agreement (for example in infringement disputes or in cases pending before the courts), a party may submit [a unilateral request for mediation](https://www3.wipo.int/amc-forms/en/adr/mediation) to the WIPO Center, by e-mail to [arbiter.mail@wipo.int](mailto:arbiter.mail@wipo.int) or through the IP Portal.

step.name: xXx_PLACEHOLDER_xXx
step.text: The WIPO Center provides complimentary procedural assistance and ADR options at reduced fees for [SMEs](https://www.wipo.int/amc/en/center/specific-sectors/smes/index.html). Interested SMEs should contact the WIPO Center on (+65) 6225 2129 (Singapore), +4122 338 82 47 (Geneva) or [arbiter.mail@wipo.int](mailto:arbiter.mail@wipo.int) for further information.

acceptedAnswer.text:
While this varies depending on the ADR process used, ADR generally offers the following benefits over dispute resolution through the court system:

* Costs are lower than court proceedings – particularly in the case of complex international disputes.
* Flexible and informal, as parties have control over shaping the process.
* Offers broader and more creative resolution solutions.
* Confidentiality, as decisions and records are not shared with the public.
* Less confrontational, helping both parties keep things from getting heated and can help preserve business relationships.
* If a dispute spans across multiple countries, a single ADR procedure can potentially resolve all the issues in one forum, saving time, reducing costs, and minimising the risk of inconsistent outcomes. Can have binding and enforceable outcomes in the form of a settlement contract or arbitral award.
* Arbitral decisions are final and cannot be appealed, unlike court rulings, while mediated settlements typically align with both parties' interests, preventing the likelihood of further dispute.
* Globally enforceable, whereas a court decision is typically confined to the jurisdiction of the country where the court is located. Using the WIPO Center’s services has the additional benefits of:
 + Procedural assistance so the process is easy to navigate and use.
 + Simplifying international disputes that involve multiple jurisdictions and languages.

* Relies on genuine engagement and willingness of parties to work out an agreement.
* Without a binding agreement prior to the process, either party can withdraw from the process at any point in time, resulting in wasted time, money and effort.

Outcomes of ADR will depend on the specific type of ADR processes used. Possible outcomes include:

* Parties successfully negotiating and reaching an agreement to resolve a dispute.
* A binding decision such as an arbitral award or an enforceable settlement agreement.
* Further escalation into court litigation.
* Parties may withdraw from the ADR process prior to resolution of the dispute.

Information, procedural assistance, and use of the WIPO Center’s [Fee Calculator](https://amc.wipo.int/adr-fee-calculator/) are free.

There are fees for using the ADR processes (mediation, arbitration, expedited arbitration or expert determination). Costs vary depending on the process used, the provider, the complexity of the case and the value of the dispute. There will be additional costs if you choose to engage a legal professional for advice and representation. Room hire and travel expenses may also apply, although most WIPO ADR processes can be done online.

You can use the WIPO Center's [fee calculator](https://amc.wipo.int/adr-fee-calculator/) and read the latest [fees and costs.](https://amc.wipo.int/adr-fee-calculator/)

[The WIPO Center offers a 25% reduction on its fees](https://www.wipo.int/amc/en/center/specific-sectors/smes/index.html) when a small to medium enterprise (SME) is involved in a dispute.

mainEntity.name: How much time might be involved?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Length of the process will vary depending on factors like the type of ADR used and the nature of the dispute. ADR can be much faster than court processes.

A typical WIPO Mediation takes 3 to 4 months, while the average duration of a WIPO Expedited Arbitration has been 6 to 7 months, and of a WIPO Arbitration 14 months These processes may be completed more rapidly at the request of the parties, for instance to ensure compliance with timelines in court referrals.

Anybody who is a party to a dispute. However, ADR options, including those provided by the WIPO Center, generally require engagement from both parties to the dispute. It can be easier to use their services if: 

* Parties agree to resolve their dispute through the WIPO Center — However, the WIPO Center allows one party to initiate mediation by submitting [a unilateral request for mediation](https://www3.wipo.int/amc-forms/en/adr/unilateral-mediation).
* There is a contract in place whereby parties agree to resolve disputes through the WIPO Center. You might wish to consider including [ADR clauses in your contracts](https://www.wipo.int/amc/en/clauses/index.html) in case you would like to resolve your future IP disputes with your business partners through ADR at the WIPO Center.

* Parties to the dispute
* WIPO Center/case manager
* Facilitator/s (mediator, arbitrator, and/or expert)
* (Optional) Legal representation for one or more of the participants
